run_metadata.article_title: The reality of trying to make US manufacturing great again
run_metadata.article_hypothesis: Tariffs raise prices without reshoring US furniture manufacturing

ideas.why: Tariff-driven input and sourcing costs are raising furniture prices, suppressing large discretionary purchases. RH is exposed to high-ticket furniture demand, which the article suggests is being delayed amid tariff uncertainty. Assumes price sensitivity persists.

Tariffs on furniture and components increase landed costs for imported goods, pressuring margins or forcing price hikes. Wayfair’s value-driven online demand is sensitive to price inflation. Assumes tariffs are not fully rolled back soon.

Rising furniture and home goods prices linked to tariffs risk dampening near-term demand. Williams-Sonoma relies on global sourcing and discretionary spending, both highlighted as under pressure. Assumes consumer pullback continues.

Even US-assembled furniture relies on imported components facing tariffs, lifting costs. The article notes suppressed large orders and price increases, directly relevant to La-Z-Boy’s core market. Assumes cost pass-through hits volumes.

key_assumptions: Tariff uncertainty and higher prices persist over the next few months
Consumers delay or cancel large furniture purchases due to inflation pressure
Partial tariff rollbacks are insufficient to restore prior demand
No rapid offset from stimulus or sudden tariff repeal
